Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GP-EXTRA: Geoscience Engagement and Outreach (GEO) - High-Impact Integrated Academic and Professional Experiences
Award.AbstractNarration:
Few students enter undergraduate programs understanding what the geosciences are or that they are part of a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) curriculum. Yet, high paying, high demand jobs in the geosciences and the need for diversity in these fields means these students may miss an opportunity to put their interests in science to work. This is especially true of students beginning their undergraduate education at two year institutions, which are play an ever increasing role in the landscape of higher education. Nearly 54% of minority students in STEM begin their undergraduate education at a community college, making efforts to engage and support such students and better prepare them to transfer to and succeed at 4-year institutions is so important. The Geoscience Engagement and Outreach (GEO) project promotes progress in science for students through the recruitment, mentoring and support of a cohort of two-year college students from underrepresented populations. Activities include faculty mentored research in a sub-set of geoscience subdisciplines, as well as skill building for careers to produce graduates prepared for the expectations of future employers. Documenting the potential of cross-institutional, integrated research and education experiences being developed through this project for retaining diverse students in the geosciences contributes to the literature on STEM recruitment and retention. The project also is expected to increase the number and caliber of faculty available to mentor undergraduates and foster continued education in the geosciences.

The GEO project is addressing barriers to engagement, recruitment, and retention of diverse students in the geosciences pipeline through an innovative three-institution collaboration that combines and leverages the strengths of Santa Fe College, a two year teaching institution; the University of Florida, a four year research institution; and the Orlando Science Center, a nonprofit informal education and outreach venue. The GEO project offers students authentic geoscience research experiences explicitly integrated with practical applications and scaffolded to classroom work. Project goals include: (1) fostering retention of the participating GEO students at Santa Fe College and transfer into Bachelor's degree programs in the geosciences, (2) strengthening collaborations among Santa Fe College teaching faculty, University of Florida researchers, and Orlando Science Center informal science educators, and (3) increasing student interest in geoscience careers through public outreach development of resources for in-service teachers. GEO's three phases of seminar-style teaching, research mentoring with outreach project development and delivery, and a culminating capstone experience scaffold the program elements into an emerging geoscience Associates degree at Santa Fe College. The project is designed to support three annual cohorts of 6 students each, with integration of peer- and supervisor-mentoring and collaborations among the three institutions. The project is targeted toward recruitment of underrepresented populations and their retention in geoscience fields. University of Florida faculty are mentoring student research in the geoscience sub-disciplines of meteorology, soil hydrology, and geoscience and STEM education. The Orlando Science Center is supervising a paid 6-week summer internship that emphasizes communications and outreach skills development. GEO students are designing and conducting outreach with diverse public audiences, teachers and high school volunteers through OSC's Otronicon. Continuation of research and outreach activities during the Fall semester culminates in the completion of a two year degree by GEO cohort students and their transfer to a four year geosciences program, prepared to continue and thrive alongside their four year institution peers. Project evaluation is measuring student content gain, using the Geoscience Concept Inventory; in addition, increases in a student's science identity and potential interest in pursuing geoscience careers are being assessed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Geoscience Education and Outreach (GEO) program provided 36 undergraduates from Santa Fe College high Impact integrated academic and professional experiences in 4 cohorts. The program recruited student Fellows underrepresented in sciences, into a program that combined classroom instruction, cohort building, mentored research and a professional internship at the Orlando Science Center.  As part of the program extension additional goals were incorporated and a 4th cohort was recruited.  


Twenty students were selected for the first 3 cohorts. In Phase I of the program classroom activities included a formal physical geography course, and a college introduction seminar with cohort building. Amenities of Santa Fe College were used to enhance cohort building. The Seahorse Key Coastal Resources Laboratory, an offshore facility with overnight accommodations, and the Santa Fe Geological Station cave were used for an annual cohort retreat.  The cohort experiences were partnered with mentored research with NSF Award 1540724. GEO Fellow cohorts worked with one of three University of Florida mentors from meteorology, science education, and agricultural engineering. Students conducted original research that culminating in a research. 


Phase II of the GEO program required relocation to the Orlando Science Center for a paid professional internship that was completed by 13 GEO Fellows over 3 cohorts. A middle school science teaching kit, that addressed the Florida science education curriculum was developed by 3 Cohorts in conjunction with the internship at Orlando Science Center.  The kits included teaching instrumentation for demonstrating and understanding heat transfer, a unit on hurricanes tracking, and a sediment flume. Three training sessions were held, and kits were provided to 53 science teachers from 12 Florida counties. Fellows experienced barriers to participation including family and employment responsibilities, transportation limitations and lack of experience in professional settings. Although Fellows were compensated for the internship and relocation to Orlando, the stipends were insufficient to overcome the need for part-time employment during the rest of the program. 

 

The objectives of Cohort 4 were to present mentored research and to internationalize the curriculum. Cohort 4 included 4 alumnae from previous cohorts.  Six student and faculty posters and two papers were presented at the Association of American Geographers, the Southeastern Division of the Association of American Geographers and the Florida Society of Geographers.  Six students travelled to Peru to conduct research and analysis, and to participate in service learning at the AbrePuertus community education center. Nine posters were presented outlining the results of the research in Peru.


Over the 4 cohorts, 24 students were retained, and 10 students have transferred to a 4-year Bachelors program to date. The undergraduate research was completed by 15 Fellows. The final year of the program (Cohort 4) afforded 6 students the opportunity to participate in research and data collection in Peru. The dissemination of research included 3 papers to peer reviewed journals, two papers and four posters presented at professional meetings.  The number of successful transfers is anticipated to increase. In the case of students from underrepresented groups, this program illustrated that a linear and timely progression through an academic career was complicated. Students were distracted by the need for employment, poor academic performance, family obligations, illness, and relocation. Each cohort included students who were the first member of their family to enter college, and students that were over 25 years of age.  Each cohort had females and Hispanic Fellows and students who were financially disadvantaged. Other underrepresented characteristics included two Veterans, a single parent and students who had earned General Education Diplomas or were dual enrolled while in high school.


The program evaluation outlined in Award 1540724 did not change students? knowledge of geosciences. However, preliminary analysis suggests that Fellows did increase their science identities. Fellows identified themselves as scientists more strongly after the program than before participating.  The exit interviews indicated that students benefited from participation in the program and found the research and internships most valuable for providing real-world job experience. Anecdotally, even students who did not complete the research or the entire program found aspects of it valuable and were able to use their experiences in securing future internships or transfer to other four-year college programs.   


The GEO program resulted in 1 student presentation and 14 student posters at formal professional meetings and College symposia. Six conference presentations and four posters documenting the program successes in recruitment, and retention, cohort building, and transfer of underrepresented students were made by Santa Fe College faculty.  Three journal manuscripts on the research experiences, overall program evaluation, and programmatic design and recommendations are under review or near to submission for review as of November 2019.
